abstract.p: Jane Bradford letter on Bruce Weber's Sept 1 article notes play Cats is based on work by T S Eliot and questions whether it will lead audience members to Eliot's other poems; drawing

block.p: Re ''The Last Meow: A Fence Sitter Sums Up'' (Critic's Notebook, Sept. 1):
Re ''The Last Meow: A Fence Sitter Sums Up'' (Critic's Notebook, Sept. 1):
Bruce Weber makes the point that the musical ''Cats'' may enlarge the audience for theatrical spectacles and eventually for theater of all kinds.

I wonder if the same spinoff effect will be true for other works of T. S. Eliot, the author of ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats,'' on which ''Cats'' is based. But I doubt it, since his name is seldom mentioned in articles about the musical, except in an offhand way.
''Cats'' is not a book of ''children's poems.'' They are poems written for the child-within-us, which is a different thing.

Perhaps some discerning members of the audience for the musical will grasp the irony and satire of the lyrics and be led to the mordant humor of ''The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock'' and ''The Waste Land.'' That would indeed be a substantial accomplishment.
JANE BRADFORD La Jolla, Calif., Sept. 1, 2000
